items.title: 1 in 10 terrorism investigations at CSIS involves a minor: spy boss
items.summary_auto: The head of Canada’s spy agency is warning about a “worrying” number of young people becoming radicalized.

items.title: Grand Theft Auto makers accused of union-busting after firing employees in Canada, U.K.
items.summary_auto: The company behind the Grand Theft Auto games fired more than 30 employees last week in what a union leader called an egregious example of union-busting, with some effects being felt in Canada.

items.title: MEG takeover saga draws to a close as Cenovus completes purchase
items.summary_auto: Oilsands giant Cenovus Energy has completed its takeover of MEG Energy, and gets another 110,000 barrels of production per day with the purchase.

items.title: Trump-appointed attorneys have been disqualified 3 times this year. Will the Comey, James prosecutor be next?
items.summary_auto: Former FBI director James Comey and current New York State Attorney General Letitia James have argued their recent indictments are politically motivated prosecutions fuelled by Donald Trump's animus. They say the appointment of Trump's hand-picked choice to oversee their cases negates their indictments altogether.

items.title: Trump-appointed attorneys have been disqualified 3 times now. Will the prosecutor who charged James Comey, Letitia James be next?
items.summary_auto: Former FBI director James Comey and current New York State Attorney General Letitia James have argued their recent indictments are politically motivated prosecutions fuelled by Donald Trump's animus. They say the appointment of Trump's hand-picked choice to oversee their cases negates their indictments altogether.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Stargazers treated to more northern lights
items.summary_auto: Solar storms brought colourful northern lights — a.k.a. aurora borealis — across much of Canada, the United States and parts of Europe for a second straight night on Wednesday.

items.title: Eating more ultra-processed foods tied to increased risk of early-onset colorectal cancer
University of Regina incorporates a stole signifying Indigenous identity for this year’s fall graduation
items.summary_auto: As 10th Chancellor of the University of Regina, Cadmus Delorme sought to ensure his Indigenous identity is reflected in his role.

items.title: Immigration Department says only 1 Kneecap band member barred from entering Canada, contradicting Liberal MP
items.summary_auto: The Immigration Department only took a decision to ban one member of the controversial Irish hip-hop trio Kneecap from entering Canada, it told CBC News, contradicting a public claim from a Liberal MP in September that none of them would be allowed in country.

items.title: Wild form of polio found in German sewage sample. What does that mean?
items.summary_auto: Despite the detection, there have been no reports of infection in Germany and scientists say the risk is minimized by high vaccination coverage.

items.title: Israeli settlers torch West Bank mosque, scrawl hateful messages
items.summary_auto: Israeli settlers torched and defaced a mosque in a Palestinian village in the central West Bank overnight, scribbling hateful messages in a show of defiance, a day after some Israeli leaders condemned a recent attack by settlers against Palestinians.

items.title: Adele to make acting debut in Tom Ford adaptation of Anne Rice's Cry to Heaven
items.summary_auto: The film is currently in pre-production with aims for a fall 2026 release, with fashion mogul Tom Ford at the helm. Ford also tapped Nicholas Hoult, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Colin Firth, Adolescence breakout Owen Cooper and Hunter Schafer for roles in the adaptation.

items.title: EU renews demand that Ukraine crack down on corruption in wake of major energy scandal
items.summary_auto: European Union officials warned Ukraine on Thursday that it must keep cracking down on graft in the wake of a major corruption scandal that could hurt the country's ability to attract financial help. But they also offered assurances that aid will continue to flow as Kyiv strains to hold back Russia's invasion.

items.title: Taps run dry as Iran faces drought crisis
items.summary_auto: Iran is grappling with its worst water crisis in decades after a scorching summer. President Masoud Pezeshkian has cautioned that if rainfall does not arrive by December, the government must start rationing water in Tehran and may even have to evacuate the city.

items.title: Saskatchewan Roughriders don’t lack in Grey Cup experience
items.summary_auto: The Grey Cup is just days away and the Saskatchewan Roughriders are putting the final touches on Sunday's game plan. It’s the first time in over 10 years that the Riders have been to the Grey Cup but the team certainly doesn't lack in Grey Cup experience.

items.title: New lung clinic to tackle Nova Scotia's long waitlists for breathing tests
items.summary_auto: A new lung clinic opening in Halifax at the end of November is hoping to tackle long waitlists for breathing tests, while also aiming to act as a recruitment tool to fill respiratory therapy vacancies in Nova Scotia.

items.title: What’s the point of getting a flu shot? Here’s what the science says
Once-curvy celebrities called 'unrecognizable' after weight loss. But why are we so mad about it?
items.summary_auto: While society's obsession with female bodies is nothing new, a wave of celebrities who embraced their larger bodies are shedding pounds — often with the help of weight-loss drugs such as Ozempic and Mounjaro — and it's touched a cultural nerve. While some have bemoaned the supposed betrayal, others point out the hypocrisy of shaming women for losing weight.

items.title: As the planet gets warmer, some athletes have taken on a new role: climate advocates
items.summary_auto: Athletes who rely on the natural environment for their sport are seeing the impact of climate change up close. And many see a responsibility to advocate for change. Canadian athletes have called on the prime minister and the IOC to make climate a top priority.

items.title: After 2 years of war, Gaza electric company takes first steps to turn the lights back on
items.summary_auto: While crews were deployed to parts of Gaza to do maintenance work on power lines, they say they face challenges that stall the work, including border closures blocking essential equipment and machinery.

items.title: Hamilton boys hockey team culture was ‘cesspool’ of bullying and sexual misconduct: adjudicator
items.summary_auto: A Hockey Canada investigation found youth hockey players in Hamilton filmed bullying and harassment of teammates. One victim’s family complained. Nearly two years later, they can talk about what happened.

items.title: Inside a Montreal clinic struggling to deal with Quebec’s imposed health reforms
items.summary_auto: Doctors at one of Montreal's largest family medicine clinics, located in Ahuntsic, say they are worried Bill 2 will make it harder to do their jobs. Since the reform was originally tabled by the Quebec government last spring, the clinic's medical director said he has lost nine family doctors.

items.title: Is there any point in getting a flu shot that's mismatched to the virus? Here’s what the science says
items.summary_auto: Some scientists say this year's flu shot isn't well matched to a key strain that could spread widely in the months ahead. So, is there still a point in getting it? Medical experts say: absolutely. Here’s why.

items.title: A post-shutdown fog will hang over the U.S. economy for months
items.summary_auto: Key economic data was not gathered during the U.S. government shut down — casting a fog of uncertainty over the state of the U.S. economy at a crucial time. The Canada-U.S. trade war has dragged on and the tariffs have begun to bite, but no one can say for certain whether that has slowed the economy.

items.title: Why The Tragically Hip are lending their songs to Boi-1da ahead of World Cup | Hanomansing Tonight
items.summary_auto: The Tragically Hip have given award-winning producer Boi-1da access to the band's entire catalogue for a special project to raise funds for the Canada Soccer Foundation. Rob Baker, guitarist for the Tragically Hip, discusses more about the project.
